title: Urban Planning for the Future
text:
Cities are where most humans now live, and their share continues to grow. How we plan and design urban areas has profound implications for quality of life, environmental sustainability, and economic prosperity. New approaches to urban planning are emerging in response to contemporary challenges.

The concept of the '15-minute city' has gained attention, particularly after the pandemic. The idea is that residents should be able to reach essential services – shops, schools, healthcare, parks, and workplaces – within a 15-minute walk or bike ride. This reduces car dependency, improves quality of life, and creates more resilient communities.

Mixed-use development, combining residential, commercial, and recreational spaces, is replacing the rigid zoning that characterized 20th-century planning. When people can live, work, and shop in the same area, transportation needs decrease and neighborhoods become more vibrant at all hours.

Green infrastructure is increasingly integrated into urban design. Parks and green corridors provide recreation, improve air quality, and reduce urban heat island effects. Green roofs and permeable surfaces manage stormwater. Urban forests and street trees provide shade while absorbing carbon dioxide.

Mobility is being reconceptualized. Cities are expanding cycling infrastructure and pedestrianizing central areas. Public transportation is being improved and electrified. Some planners envision cities where private car ownership becomes unnecessary.

Housing affordability presents an ongoing challenge. Many desirable cities have become unaffordable for ordinary workers, driving inequality and long commutes. Solutions being explored include social housing, inclusionary zoning, and reducing regulatory barriers to construction.

Resilience planning prepares cities for climate change impacts. Coastal cities must plan for rising seas and storm surges. All cities must prepare for more extreme heat. Green infrastructure helps, but engineering solutions and emergency preparedness are also essential.

The cities we build today will shape how billions of people live for generations. Getting urban planning right has never been more important.
